intro_bio: Kirsten Marie was the daughter of Ane Rasmusdatter and Peder Andersen, a small holder and tenant farmer, who later managed to buy a farm. She learned most of her stories and legends from her mother who had learned them, in turn, from her father. He was such a good teller that he could gather all the people at a party around him to hear his stories. Her brother was Rasmus Kjær Pedersen, a farm owner, who introduced Tang Kristensen to her. She was the best informant that Tang Kristensen met on his collecting trip in the spring of 1890 in eastern Jutland, and she continued to be one of his best informants. Tang Kristensen enjoyed visiting her house, not only because she was an eager and competent informant, but also because of the warm reception he received from her, her husband and her daughter.

Jens’s father was a cobbler and fiddler from Tveden and his mother was from Årestrup. He had always helped his father with shoemaking but, when he was strong enough, he also helped with the harvest. He had lived his whole life in the same area. He was a veteran of the 1848 war. His mother often sang the many ballads she knew, but did so mono-tonally. His father was a good singer, and Jens learned the melodies to his ballads from him. Jens had sung many ballads with highwayman and railroad guard Johan Pingel. Jens said that everything he told was drivel and nonsense which was not worth listening to. His wife did not like him telling such stories. Tang Kristensen mentions that “Heldigvis stikker hun jævnlig ud til naboerne”. He was an eager narrator, well-versed in the ways and mind-set of the old people, including the old dialect of the area. His sister also was able to sing several ballads for Tang Kristensen, but was not as good an informant. His son from his second marriage, Anders Bundgaards, became a famous sculptor.

Kirsten Marie was the daughter of Ane Rasmusdatter and Peder Andersen, a small holder and tenant farmer, who later managed to buy a farm. She learned most of her stories and legends from her mother who had learned them, in turn, from her father. He was such a good teller that he could gather all the people at a party around him to hear his stories. Her brother was Rasmus Kjær Pedersen, a farm owner, who introduced Tang Kristensen to her. She was the best informant that Tang Kristensen met on his collecting trip in the spring of 1890 in eastern Jutland, and she continued to be one of his best informants. Tang Kristensen enjoyed visiting her house, not only because she was an eager and competent informant, but also because of the warm reception he received from her, her husband and her daughter.

intro_bio: Margrete was the illegitimate daughter of Bodil Nielsdatter and cobbler/husmand, Jens Hansen. She was raised by her father, as her mother had died when Margrete was four years old. According to family tradition, her grandfather had worked in the royal court and her father had been playmates with King Frederik the Sixth. Her father had traveled out of the country as a soldier and, upon his return, had received land from the court. He had many books and was a good story teller and singer, especially of folk tales and ballads. She learned many of her stories and ballads from traveling tradesmen and learned them easily. She was a congenial and adept narrator and singer.

Jens lived alone in his house in Ilbjærge, and told Tang Kristensen that he was a widower. This self-characterization was not entirely true, and his biography is one filled with unexpected twists. He was the son of Peder Christian Pedersen, a husmand, and Johanne Nielsdatter. He had learned many of his stories from his father, although his mother and maternal grandmother also told many stories. He lived in poverty and enjoyed talking to Tang Kristensen. Once he walked through the pouring rain to meet up with Tang Kristensen, so he could tell him more stories.

Peder was the son of miller and fiddler, “Kat-Søren,” and this led him to become a miller. His grandfather was a well-known folk healer and an exceptional story teller. Peder had learned many of his stories from this grandfather, but could not remember all of the stories he had heard from him. He lived in a house near the mill, and his sister kept house for him, as he had never been married. He was apparently a slob, and these habits carried over to the hygienic standards of his mill. He later moved to Vrold and then Dover. He was good story teller, but was often busy with fiddling for area parties. Tang Kristensen collected many of his stories in the millhouse, while the mill guests sat about drinking.
